segments.text: Karen, thanks for pulling together the Q4 numbers. Let's go through this before the board meeting next week.
Of course. Overall we're in good shape. Revenue was up 18% year over year, hitting 47.2 million.
That's solid growth. What about margins? I know material costs have been volatile.
Margins compressed slightly to 12.8% from 13.5% last year. Steel and lumber price increases ate into profitability.
Have we been passing those costs to clients through change orders?
On new contracts, yes. But we have three legacy fixed-price contracts where we're absorbing the increases. That's about 400k in lost margin.
Ouch. When do those contracts complete?
Two finish in Q1, the third in Q2. After that, we should see margins recover back to the 13-14% range.
Good. What's our cash position looking like? Are we comfortable with the line of credit?
We've got 3.2 million in cash and we're using about 40% of our credit line. Days payable outstanding is at 52 days, which is healthy.
And receivables? Any clients dragging their feet on payments?
Most are current. We have one client 90 days past due for 180k. I've been in contact with them - they're having cash flow issues.
Westfield Properties. The retail plaza project.
I'll call their CEO directly. We can't let that age any further. If they can't pay, we need to know now so we can take action.
Agreed. On the positive side, our backlog is strong - 62 million in signed contracts for next year.
That's excellent. And if we land Riverside, that adds another 12.8. We're setting up for a strong 2025.
Absolutely. My recommendation is we invest in another project manager and a senior estimator to support the growth.
I agree. Put together a hiring plan and budget. Let's get those positions posted next week.

environment.background_sounds: quiet office, papers rustling, calculator clicking
